Award.AwardTitle: School and Workshop on Geometry Discrete Actions - ICTP
Award.AbstractNarration:
The School and Workshop on the Geometry of Discrete Group Actions will be held at the International Centre for Theoretical Physics from 24 August to 4 September, 2015 in Trieste, Italy. Discrete group actions can be thought of as extensions of tilings that you might see on walkways or the configurations of molecules found in crystals. This field of mathematics continues to evolve and surprise. During he first week of the activity (the school), international experts in the field will give several mini-courses for young researchers from across the globe. The workshop, held during the second week, will be where established researchers will exchange their newest results in this field. Both activities will enhance communication between researchers from the U.S. and the rest of the world, especially young researchers from historically underrepresented groups and countries.



The Abdus Salam International Centre for Theoretical Physics will host the School and Workshop on Geometry Discrete Actions from 24 August to 4 September 2015 in Trieste, Italy. The organizers of the school and workshop are Bertran Deroin (Ecole Normale Superieure, France), Todd A. Drumm (Howard University, DC, USA), John Parker (University of Durham, UK), and Jose Seade (Universidad Nacional Autonoma de Mexico, Mexico). Discrete actions on geometric spaces are of historic and current interest in mathematics. Students of mathematics are often first introduced these ideas with tilings of the plane, but the complexity of the actions and the geometries considered have been expanded on many times over. The interconnections between seemingly disparate schools of thought are a hallmark of this field, as is the interaction between the geometric and more dynamical properties of the discrete actions. The relatively newer studies of Character Varieties and Higher Teichmuller Theory are a natural and fertile continuation of this tradition. The general themes for this activity were inspired by the Sullivan-McMullen dictionary in complex dimension 2. This school and workshop will be a unique blend of complex geometry, hyperbolic geometry, and Lorentzian geometry. The purpose of this activity is to introduce young mathematicians to the themes of this activity and present some of recent developments in these fields of study. The school will consist of 5 short courses will include courses on Hyperbolic Surfaces, Lorentzian Geometry, Complex Hyperbolic Geometry< Kleinian Groups, and Character Varieties. These courses will be aimed at the upper graduate student level and will serve as an introduction to current research. The workshop, held during the second week of the activity, will concentrate on new results by invited researchers. Young mathematicians and established researchers will benefit from seeing presentation on the latest results. At the end of the conference, a session will be devoted to open problems related to the themes of the activity. The interaction between researchers working in developing countries, European researchers and U.S.-based researchers is an especially important part of activity.

The location of the school at workshop at ICTP, whose website contains additional information about the institute, plays a vital role in this mission.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Travel Grant for the Advanced School and Workshop on Geometry of Discrete Actions at the ICTP

             The school and workshop were held at The Abdus Salam International Centre for Theoretical Physics (ICTP) in Trieste, Italy. The National Science Foundation was listed as at Co-sponsor as can be seen at the activities website

            http://indico.ictp.it/event/a14294/

The school and workshop was held from 24 August to 4 September, 2015 and was organized by Bertran Deroin (Ecole Normale Superieure, France), Todd A. Drumm (Howard University), John Parker (University of Durham, UK) and Jose Seade (Universidad Nacional Autonoma de Mexico, Mexico). The final list of participants is avaialable on the website.

            The first week was the school, with the goal of introducing graduate students from underrepresented parts of the world to research in the geometry of discrete actions. The school consisted of the following courses. 

  • Lorentzian Geometry by T. Drumm, 3 lectures.
  • Complex Dynamics and Character Varieties by
    B. Deroin, 3 lectures.
  • Complex Hyperbolic Geometry by J. Parker, 3 lectures.
  • Hyperbolic surfaces and Teichmuller Theory by
                F. Gueritaud (Lab. Paul Painleve, France). 3 lectures.
  • Limit Sets of Discrete Groups by J. Seade, 3 lectures.
  • Introduction to Holomorphic Dynamics by
                R Dujardin (LAMA, U. Paris Est France), 2 lectures.
  • An Introduction to Higher Teichmuller Theory
    by Richard Canary (University of Michigan), 2 lectures.

            All of the lectures were recorded, and those videos can be found at the programme part of the website.

            http://indico.ictp.it/event/a14294/other-view?view=ictptimetable

Slides and course materials for several of the courses are also publically available at that site. Drumm has recently had a student from India remark that he had indeed watched the lectures. The courses by Parker and Seade are also parts of preprints for books that circulated among the participants. All of the courses are excellent introductions into the subspecialties for any student.

            The workshop, with the main goal of dissemination of the most current research, was held during the second week. Current research in different subspecialties was presented by a speaker list that spanned the globe. The entire schedule is on the programme part of the website. A few highlights are here.

  • z-Classes in Geometry and Groups by
    R. Kulkarni (IIT Mumbai, India).
  • Do Limits Sets Move Continuously by
    C. Series (University of Warwick, UK).
  • On representations of the fundamental group of the whitehead link complement in PU}(2,1) by
                P. Will (Fourier Institut, Grenoble, France).
  • The Einstein Universe by
    V. Charette (University of Sherbrooke, Canada).
  • Commensurability of Hyperbolic Coxeter Groups by
    R. Kellerhals (University of Fribourg, Switzerland).
  • Marked Length Spectral Rigidity for Flat Metrics by
    C. Leininger (Univ. of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign)
  • Anti-de Sitter 3-manifolds, Margulis space-times, and their higher-dimensional analogues by
                F. Kassel ( Universite Lille, France).
  • Identities on Hyperbolic Surfaces by
    S. R. Tan (National University of Singapore, Singapore).

All of the talks for the workshop were also recorded, and the videos can be found on the website. There was also a Poster Session for graduate students and recent Ph. D.'s. Near the end of the workshop, a recorded problem session was also held.

            The reaction from the participants was very positive, and the atmosphere was collegial. Many contacts were established between the students and faculty.
